search_result.title: Georgia football coach Kirby Smart on roster caps and 2026 schedule
search_result.text:
MIRAMAR BEACH, Fla.—When Kirby Smart first came to the SEC spring meetings as a head coach in 2016, there were just five media members who met with him when he arrived at the Emerald Room B at the Sandestin Beach Hilton.

That’s mostly because Smart was delayed getting a rental car at the airport that day which pushed his time up against that of Alabama coach Nick Saban and Smart went to a different room.

Now as probably the most prominent head coach in college football after the retirement in January of Saban, Smart commanded the Theatre room early Tuesday afternoon as the last of five football coaches to stand in the front of the room of reporters and take questions before the coaches' meetings began.

There’s a lot to talk about.

“It’s probably in the nine years I’ve been apart of this, the most anticipated meetings because there’s so much left to not have us decide, but to have input on because some of it is beyond our decision-making process,” Smart said. “There’s a lot there.”

Here's some of what Smart talked about:

Kirby Smart on capping football rosters

There’s discussion after the NCAA settlement in three antitrust cases that will pay nearly $2.8 billion in damages to current and former athletes and share about 22 percent of a Power Conference school’s revenue a year that roster sizes may be capped.

“That’s what we’re here for to try to figure that out,” Smart said. “I do feel strongly that roster spots are important and walk-ons are important. Where that falls that’s what we’re here to decide.”

In football, the number being bandied about is 85 which would jeopardize walk-on spots.

“I don’t know anybody that wouldn’t defend walk-ons,” Smart said. “We’re talking about something that just makes sense. When you implement that known fact into some form of settlement that I don’t completely understand, I don’t know where that factors in.”

He mentioned Dabo Swinney, Will Muschamp, and Ladd McConkey “as guys that have come to schools as walk-ons and then gone to be successful football players, successful coaches, successful at everything they do.”

McConkey signed with Georgia, but received mostly smaller school offers.

How expanded playoff may impact UGA football making 12-team field

Smart has taken Georgia to the College Football Playoff in three of his eight seasons and has come close in other seasons including last year where Georgia was 12-1 after an SEC Championship game loss to Alabama

“There are probably three times that we were one of the best four teams but we didn’t earn it on the field,” said Smart who won national titles in 2021 and 2022.

Now the playoff is expanding from four to 12 teams., but there will still be debate about those left out.

Just like with college baseball bracket Monday and the college basketball March Madness bracket.

“The same opportunity is going to present itself, it’s just going to be 13, 14, 15,” Smart said. “You guys are going to debate a lot about it. I’m going to try to make my team better so they’re not 13, 14, 15.”

Eight game schedule for next two seasons. What about 2026?

The SEC is sticking with an eight game schedule for 2024 and 2025 with the same opponents just flipping locations.

There will be discussion this week about 2026 and beyond but no decisions are expected.

“It’s a hot button topic,” Smart said. “It’s on y’all’s little memo, it says ask the question about eight or nine games. I’m completely cool with that question. I don’t care about eight or nine. I don’t care one bit. If you tell me we’re going to get more teams in by playing nine, I vote for that. If we’re going to have a strength of schedule factor that says these teams that play really hard teams, they should be allowed to have two or three losses and get in then I’m for it. It doesn’t help us, then you can say why do it? The fan, the guy’s that pays the ticket price wants those games.”

search_result.title: Plenty to ponder throughout NDI's latest Notre Dame men's ...
search_result.text:
Thomas Noie: And....we're off and running with another college basketball season. The games came quickly and not very easily for the Notre Dame men's basketball program the first five weeks. A lot of games away from home, a lot of losses, a lot of lessons learned as the Irish are 4-5 while working through finals week. There has to be plenty to discuss - so let's discuss. Include your name and hometown with your question or comment. And with that, let's light this chat candle...

joe from the south side: Tom, Biggest changes from Mike to Micah? 1. Accountability. At times, Brey threw it over the fence and said let the old guys figure it out. Not now. It begins with MS. It goes thru MS. It ends with MS. Period. Maybe as they mature, that will change. For now, Micah's way or the highway. 2. Hustle. No more winning 86-80 with this team. So, you rebound, you move the ball, you move yourself and you play defense. Failure to do so means a seat on the pines. 3. Recruiting. This guy is leaving no stone unturned. If you fit ND and MS, he's coming for you. Your thoughts?Thomas Noie: A few. The first of which is, let's not get THAT carried away with the changes. Brey decided in 2021-22 to coach the "fabric" of the program and let the heavy lifting to the assistants, but that also produced a 15-5 record in the Atlantic Coast Conference and a near-miss of another Sweet 16. It worked then, it just didn't work last year when he put it in the hands of the veterans who weren't able to handle the heavy lifting. Mike Brey had his faults, and plenty of them, but you don't win the way he won at Notre Dame with smoke and mirrors. Micah Shrewsberry is learning that the job at Notre Dame is HARD. On and off the floor, it's not going to be easy. That said, I love, love, love what I've seen from Shrewsberry. Sometimes, I find myself watching him more than the five guys on the floor. The energy, the emotions, it's exactly what this program needs. Now. We don't get 86-80 any more, but are you content with 65-53? You can hustle and defend and still score.Thomas Noie: Recruiting? This staff has been everywhere and looked at everyone it needs to look at it. That's the easy part. The hard part now is getting them to campus and getting them into the program. Remember, the class Notre Dame signed last month, each one of the prospects had previous relationships with either Shrewsberry or the staff. it was just a carry over from the groundwork he laid at Penn State. Now do it at Notre Dame. There's a lot to like about Micah Shrewsberry, but he'll be the first to admit there's a long way still to go. It's on the right track.

Dave Nation: The team seems to be underperforming even your tempered expectations. What aspect has disappointed you the most? Effort or execution?Thomas Noie: Dave: Disagree. This was going to be a really difficult season, for myriad reasons. Notre Dame lost to Western Carolina, but when you looked at Western Carolina and saw that it had three senior guards who were all preseason all-conference selections, your antennae should've rocketed up. The Irish were in trouble based on that fact alone. Notre Dame wasn't ready for Auburn, was a little more ready for South Carolina and had zero business playing Miami and Marquette at that point in the schedule. At 4-5, they're about right where they were expected to be. They're competing their #$%@ off, they're learning to play together. They just don't know how to win. That will come as we move deeper through this season. Maybe that translates to 6-14 or 7-13 in league play. Maybe it doesn't. As for biggest disappointment, it would be the lack of awareness of everything on offense. Shot-clock violations (four in the first 11 minutes against Marquette) are a result of guys just not knowing what to do and when to do it.

Guest: How’s notre dame doing with Moreno the 25 big I think there missing a good post player who can defend block some shotsThomas Noie: That would be Malachi Moreno, a 6-foot-11, 210-pound consensus four-star/Top 100 prospect from Georgetown, Kentucky. The standard recruiting answer would be, yeah, they're good with him, but really, does anyone know about a prospect who has 23 schools (who all have offered) on his wish list? Short answer - no. Notre Dame did its work early with Moreno, but will that be enough for him to choose Notre Dame over Alabama, Baylor, Creighton, Indiana, Kentucky and Purdue among others? Micah Shrewsberry can sell immediate playing time, but that might not be enough. Notre Dame is in the mix with Moreno. That's all you can ask on Dec. 13.

Guest: I can see the young talent I think the future is bright just need better post play and maybe another wing that can defend or big guardThomas Noie: The future is bright, but if given a choice, I'd say Micah Shrewsberry would add a proven post player and a another wing/big guard who can score. Defense has rarely been the issue. These guys guard. The issue has been that when Notre Dame needs a bucket, it doesn't have the luxury of throwing it into the post for someone to collapse the defense and/or get a bucket and get fouled. It doesn't have that one guy who just says, F this, and goes and drives the lane and finishes and is fouled and make a free throw. It really needed a veteran scorer on the perimeter with this group. I won't say they didn't try to get one - maybe admissions had other ideas. Dare I say it - this team needs a cocky/confident guy like Prentiss Hubb (ducks).

Mike from columbus: Love this team. Haven’t seen this much hustle for quite a while except for Njie. Is the hand holding him back or does he need a big dose of nasty.Thomas Noie: Mike: Agree 1000 percent on the hustle part. Like Micah Shrewsberry has often said, he's not going to coach effort. If you're going to play, you're going to play hard. The guys have shown it, but are still learning it. The effort wasn't anywhere where it needed to be in the first half against Marquette. The second half, though it was really just a scrimmage, the effort was better. Shrewsberry said afterward that the tape won't lie - he'll see how hard guys played in the second half. Now go play that way from the jump. As for Kebba Njie, it might be part hand, part head. It's been a struggle for him to get back into full go with the right hand injury, which has led to him overthinking everything. He just needs to settle in and get a few easy baskets. That can get him going. We also have to remember that he's only a sophomore. He played every game last year at Penn State, but wasn't one of the main guys. Rotating into that role is difficult as it is. Even more so coming back from injury/ineffectiveness.

Johnny in NC: What number of wins would be considered a success this year?Johnny in NC: Can ND win four ACC games this year?Thomas Noie: Johnny: Two for one answer coming here. Notre Dame is 4-5 heading into Saturday's home game against Georgetown. That starts a season-high six-game homestand (three non-conference, three conference). Good teams, or OK teams learning to be good have, have, have to win at home. Notre Dame should win those three non-conference home games - Georgetown, The Citadel, Marist - which gets the Irish to 7-5 jumping back to league play. The Irish are 0-1 in the ACC. My projection at the start was this team could win six league games somewhere along the line. That would leave the Irish 13-19 heading to the league tournament. Think everyone would take that given what we've seen to date, right?

Avila: Love the fresh start. It was past time. Will Shrew use the portal or develop young talent? Good luck….don’t let Duke intimidate you……Thomas Noie: Avila: It was time for a change. Mike Brey would be the first to admit that - he should've left after the 2022 NCAA tournament run, but was fooled into thinking that team last year could recreate what happened in 2021-22. Didn't have it in them. It happens. Reset button was pressed. Micah Shrewsberry will utilize the transfer portal to fit a specific need. A guy here, maybe two guys there, but it's never going to be a case like it is at Georgetown, which comes to town Saturday with 10 - TEN! - transfers on its roster. It will be recruiting, recruiting, recruiting, then player development, player development, player development. This staff is better set up to do that than the last one.

Chad from Toledo: Not to be rude or anything but you can practice defense all year round and no one is shutting teams out in Basketball correct?? Bottom line is to score more points than your opponent Yes?? The game has changed a lot since shot clock for sure!! Can you explain the process Coach Shrewsberry is trying to build when Offense wins games n defense is ND focal point? I do like this team so far but ND needs to score the ball more n hope to play defense well enough to win!Out rebounding teams is the best defense you can play!Markus Burton body will not hold up dribbling the entire possession to create offense! Your thoughts on ND best scoring option at 5’11”!! Luv the kids game but he needs help? Go IrishThomas Noie: Chad: Facts, which is why I've pushed back on this narrative from Notre Dame men's basketball "fans" who have holler "Hallelujah!" every time Micah Shrewsberry has mentioned defense. Like, be careful what you wish for in that regard. Yes, Notre Dame has and will continue to guard, but it also is offensively challenged. That's not coaching as much as it is personnel. Look at the grouping that are on the floor. Freshmen. Transfers. A junior (J.R. Knoieczny) who basically sat out for two years. It's an impossible ask to put any combination of five guys on the floor and have them figure it out against the teams it has had to figure it out against. There is ability there - we saw it when they scored a season high 86 points last week against Western Michigan. But when your best option is Markus Burton going and getting something, you're going to rank 335th in the country for scoring offense (64.2 ppg.). This program needs a walking bucket. It doesn't have one.

Pat H. Springfield Illinois: Who’s being recruited and for what positions? Thanks for hosting this and keep up your good workThomas Noie: Pat: Good question, but first a roster breakdown for 2024-25 - If, and that's always going to be a huge IF, nobody jumps to the transfer portal in the spring, Notre Dame will have a maximum 13 players on scholarship, which includes former walk-on Alex Wade and current seniors Tony Sanders and Matt Zona, who each have their COVID-19 bonus seasons remaining for 2024-25. So after 2024-25, if this roster stays together, Notre Dame will have four scholarships (Wade, Julian Roper, Zona, Sanders) to offer the 2025 class. That said, Notre Dame's future classes will look a lot like its first two - versatile guards/post players. Here's who visited this fall from the Class of 2025 and Class of 2026...Thomas Noie: 2025 prospects: Azavier Robinson (G), Colt Laydon (F), E.J. Walker (F), Dezmon Bruce (F), Christian Gurdak (C), Malachi Moreno (C), Braylon Mullins (G), Jalen Haralson (F), Niko Bundalo (F), Gregory Lawson (G). 2026 prospects: Taylen Kinney (G), Steven Reynolds (G), Jonathan Sanderson (G), T.J. Crumble (F).

Billy Mac: Tom - During scoring droughts this year the only “go to” seems to be Marcus Burton’s pull-up mid range jumper that he seems to be able to get when he wants. Do you see a time when Coach Schrews puts the ball in someone else’s hand and lets Marcus hunt his shot a bit when needed? Thanks as always for the chat!Thomas Noie: How about a definite maybe? As in, maybe when these guys have a clearer idea of who can do what and when, Micah Shrewsberry will trust Markus Burton to move off the ball and Tae Davis to move on it. Given Burton's size, though, he's easy to guard off the ball. He's best with the ball in his hands, getting to the midrange them - boom! - he stops and sticks that mid-range pull-up while the defense still is retreating. That should be in his bag every single time. It's hard watching him struggle from 3 the way he has (7-of-33, .212 percent). He's not a 3-point shooter yet, and that's OK. That will come. Same with trusting someone else besides Burton to get into some semblance of offense. Burton leads the Irish with 33 assists. Logan Imes is the only other player in double figures for assists with 10. Keep the ball in Burton's hands and let him create. That works best for where the Irish are for now.

P.Rose: What happened to Tony Sanders?Thomas Noie: P: Let me flip the question - why should Tony Sanders play more than the 6:47 he's logged in two games? If he could help in any way, don't you think he would've helped? Right now, there are guys Micah Shrewsberry trusts more (i.e. defends) better than Sanders. Just gotta keep working and maybe the rotation swings his way.

Guest: Why does Shrewsberry stay in the game when he gets beat off the dribble from the wing for an easy lay up with barely a defensive effort to even attempt to stop the dribble drive penetration for the easy basket.Thomas Noie: For a team that ranks 335th in the country for scoring (64.2 ppg.) it's hard to take one of the few guys who can maybe make a shot off the floor. For the most part, Braeden Shrewsberry has defended and has competed. There are times when he looks overmatched/overwhelmed, but that's the case with just about everybody on the roster. It's not just a Shrewsberry thing.

Patrick from NYC: Tom, now that we've gotten a good look at a pretty big rotation (a little delayed on Kebba Njie) who has been the most pleasant surprise? I'm going with JR followed closely by Tae DavisThomas Noie: Patrick: Good call, but after the Western Michigan game, I wrote that Tae Davis has been a revelation, so my pick to date would be Davis, second on the squad in scoring (9.4) and first in rebounding (5.8). He's also been asked to do the most, and it's not even close. He's guarded guards. He's guarded forwards. He's been a secondary handler to Markus Burton. J.R. Konieczny would be No. 2 in terms of pleasant surprises. Both are solid pieces as this moves forward.

Alex: The team plays hard there is no doubt about that. Through 9 games are they better/worse/or about where you expected them to be with such a roster turnaround? This schedule has been a gauntlet for such a brand new/inexperienced group. More difficult than I remember any schedule being under the previous regime.Thomas Noie: Alex: Not going to sit here and say, called this and called that and knew this and knew that, but nine games in, Notre Dame is about where it's supposed to be. The Irish have competed and shown signs here and there that they MIGHT be good, but they just haven't sustained it. There has reached a point in every loss to a Power Six team (Auburn, South Carolina, Miami, Marquette) where the other team can and has hit another gear and the Irish are seemingly stuck in neutral. Happened right from the start against Marquette, but I agree with Micah Shrewsberry - Notre Dame had ZERO business playing that game. Not at this time. Not with that team. Not against that team. What happened last weekend in Milwaukee was expected. Shrewsberry was right when he said earlier this month that this Notre Dame is one that should've been at home for the entire months of November and December to get some wins and some confidence. The Irish weren't ready for the road, but maybe somewhere along the way, it will make them better.

Jack from Rye, NY: While I love the defensive effort-excluding first half at Marquette-it’s obvious we don’t have much talent and/or experience. Mike Brey was often criticized for being a lazy recruiter but compare his last 2 classes with Micah Shrewsberry. Sophomores JJ Starling and Ven Allen Lubin ( double double for Vandy last week) are certainly more productive than Kenna Njie ( 1-17!!! from inside 5 feet) and this year Burton, Parker Friedrichson (19 points for Wake last week) and Brady Dunlap ( little time at St Johns) are certainly more talented and productive than Braeden S, Imes, and Booth. Should we be concerned about recruiting the talent necessary to bring program to the heights that we all hope for? That being said, I do love 2024 class but let’s see what happensThomas Noie: Jack: Soapbox time. Look at my X (Twitter) mentions after almost every single Notre Dame loss this season, and you're bound to come across a thread (or two or three) about how all this is Mike Brey's fault, which I find hilarious. Like, fans.....really? Mike Brey had his faults, but he had a freshman class of Dom Campbell, Ven-Allen Lubin and J.J. Starling, a McDonald's All-American. He had an incoming class that included Markus Burton and Parker Friedrichsen and Brady Dunlap. When Brey left, he encouraged all six of those guys to see who Notre Dame hired before deciding their futures. Only Burton followed through. The other five all left for other schools. That's Brey's fault? Would Starling fit nicely with this team? Would Lubin be sorely needed? Yes, times 10.Thomas Noie: That Notre Dame is challenged in many areas right now is nobody's "fault." The previous head coach had to go, the new head coach came in and guys decided to transfer. It's the way of the college basketball world. Booth is so young he should really be a high school senior right now. Imes is a program guy who fits best as a third or fourth guard. Shrewsberry would be the perfect sniper on a veteran/old/experienced team. All three HAVE to play now - there are no other options. That anyone would be "concerned" given what Micah Shrewsberry inherited/had to work with is laughable. Let's give this three years and see where it is. It's not going to happen any sooner.

WoofCookie: I think they are trying hard on defense, but I've noticed that other teams can set up a pick and roll and get a pretty easy 8-10 foot shoot. Do you think that's just "young" and "inexperience" of the team / learning to play with each other, etc..?Thomas Noie: Woof: This group is still too young and inexperienced where they don't know what they don't know. Pick and roll is basic basketball, right Playing it, defending it. All of it. But it's also perfected by guys who know/sense/anticipate what the other guys is going to do. How they're going to guard it, how they're going to roll off it. It takes hundreds of hours in the gym. Sometimes thousands to make it look so smooth. This group, even nine days in, still resembles a noon-time pickup of five guys who don't know one another but are expected to compete at that level. That's a hard ask. Even as well as they've played on defense, there's been leakage. Why? The trust isn't there either. Time.

Mark from Rochester: I know this is year 1, but do you like the non conference scheduling change under Micah? Seems to be a lot harder than the cupcakes we’re used to seeing in November and December.Thomas Noie: Mark: Nope. Hate it. Hate it, hate it, hate it. So does Micah Shrewsberry because outside of Saturday's home game against Georgetown, Shrewsberry had very little say in this season's schedule. He's said it before, so I'll say it again. This is a Notre Dame program that should've been at home playing any directional school it could find for November and December. The Legends Classic? That was tied into the previous coaching regime. Notre Dame had no business playing at Barclays three games in. Same for the game at Marquette. That was a Mike Brey leftover. Shrewsberry really should've asked Shaka Smart to put it on pause for a year. The game at South Carolina was a directive by the league under the ACC/SEC Challenge. Shrewsberry said after that one that Notre Dame also will be on the road (team TBD) for next year's ACC/SEC Challenge. If there was ever a year and a team that needed to feast on those "cupcakes" it's this one. This schedule did this program a disservice in every conceivable way.

Mark from Rochester: What have you seen from Markus Burton over the past month? Started hot but then played better competition and dipped a bit. Excited to see his growth in the program!Thomas Noie: Mark: The ebbs and flows for a freshman guard. It was easy early because nobody knew about him. What could he do? How good could he be? There was no film, no scout, no nothing on him. He was a blank slate. As those color by number patterns started to be filled in, teams understood better what he could and what they could do to take him away. Especially against older guards who'd been there and done it at that level. SO Burton hits a rough patch. But good players figure it out. He's figured it out, though it would be nice to see him not hunt his 3-point shot as much (.212 percent). He's lethal in the mid-range. Get to those spots and be good. A lot there to build on.

Ryan mars pa: Tom what do you think About Both players from south bend area Jr and Burton are having a good year so farThomas Noie: Ryan: Good first steps both for Markus Burton and J.R. Konieczny. Point guard is the toughest position to learn/play/know/excel at in college. Burton's had his moments. So has Konieczny. Love how both compete. Konieczny has shown a toughness that we didn't know he had. They'll only get better in this program, which stresses player development way more than the previous staff.

joe from the south side: Tom, I've only seen vs. AUB and vs. MARQ. Both very bad matchups. That said, they are a step slow on both ends. Part of that is learning Micah's system, part is they were just not as athletic as those two schools. The offense, other than Marcus, maybe Davis a little, seems unable to create for themselves. Which makes ball movement and personnel movement paramount, two things I didn't see much of. MARQ picked them up at the 3 point line and ND was satisfied to run the Globetrotter weave and then force a three before the buzzer. They need to establish either Njie or Davis in the post. Maybe get 8 to 10 points to free up the perimeter. Like with Atkinson. Defense shows some hustle but they lack foot quickness and could really use an inside presence. Someone, who when he fouls you, you think twice about going in there again. Thoughts?Thomas Noie: Joe: Don't take it personally (I know you won't) but it's kind of asking Mrs. Lincoln that, well, other than the obvious, how did you enjoy the play?😃 Notre Dame shouldn't have played either of those teams for all the reasons outlined in your post. Maybe next year or the year after they'll have the pieces and the parts and poise to counter everything they saw against Auburn and Marquette. Maybe then, they'll have that inside presence and a guy like a Ben Hansbrough who can be like #$%$# this stuff, I'm going to get a bucket. There are so many missing pieces right now that asking about Auburn or Marquette or what's coming in the league (Duke, Virginia, Clemson) just sets it up for frustration.

Mark from Rochester: Tom is there going to be an emphasis on getting shooters in recruiting? Outside of Shrewsberry who needs time and confidence, there arent any threats on our perimeter. Teams seem to be ok with Davis and Roper taking those. Thank you!Thomas Noie: Mark: Notre Dame assistant coach Ryan Owens classified Cole Certa, who's signed to arrive next season, as the finest shooter in the country. So there's that. And Braeden Shrewsberry, Burton, Tae Davis, Logan Imes all can and should be better than what they've shown from distance to date.

Andrew from Plymouth: How about Russell Carter instead of Prentis Hubb?Thomas Noie: Whoa....the Russell Carter we saw senior year, sure. But it took three years to get there. For him to get there. Hubb was a #$%#@ you guy from the start.

Clancy: Marquette made us look lost at times. Under Brey, I remember thinking how did he set up practice when there were so few quality players on the practice squad to mimic these tougher opponents. How do you think Micah’s approach to practice players is going?Thomas Noie: Clancy: Unbelievably different, in the best way possible. Well, from the little we could see. A little "here's how the sausage is made" sidebar. The plan for the fall was that we'd see a full practice at Rolfs Hall. That full practice was shaved to 20 minutes of basically just individual instruction. But if you paid attention, you knew this was not your Mike Brey Irish program any more. There were times last year when they couldn't even go five-on-five because of a lack of bodies. That's not an issue under Micah Shrewsberry, who carries five walk-ons. At one point during that preseason session, I counted 27 people on the court in some form of coaching, playing, managing, instructing manner. Not having enough players to practice never will be an issue with this staff.

Tyler from Granger: Tom, what makes moving the basketball the most difficult/challenging for a young team in college basketball? Not necessarily this team but your general opinion. Is it the speed of the college game? Emphasis on coaching philosophy? Chemistry? Individual talent? ThanksThomas Noie: Tyler: A little of everything, but especially trust. I have to trust that my teammate is going to be at a certain spot at a certain moment without wondering/worrying, which is what we've seen from the Irish. Too much wondering. Too much maybes and not enough certainty. That comes with practice reps and doing it again and again and again in games and on the practice court. Especially in the summers when that trust can be built. Notre Dame couldn't do any of that in June and July - it was too busy trying to figure out the new head coach and the new staff and the campus and the expectations. This is a group that needs to be locked in a gym for days so they can just play. Move and operate and think as one where they just know where the ball and the other guys are going next. Trust.

Illinois Fool: Your comment on not having a walking bucket certainly shows up late in the shot clock. The players either don't recognize the clock is running down or are reluctant to put up a "bad shot". Do you see this as something that will improve with game experience or a year long problem?Thomas Noie: IF: Look at my answer (above or below or how this chat flows) for that. Trust is a big reason for the shot-clock issues. That and just having that clock in your head to know, OK, gotta go. These guys have so many other thoughts going on - shoot it, move it, dribble it, space it - that they really do forget about the shot clock. I believe that. They're so robotic in their movements, again, because they don't know yet how to just play. It will improve. It has to improve.

Clint from Winnipeg: Is this season more interesting than last simply because you see individual and collective improvement with each game, where last year the veteran group was what it was and the ceiling pretty much had been reached?Thomas Noie: Clint: Absolutely. Times 100. There's something new and different and intriguing to see every single time Notre Dame plays. Win or lose. Yes, Saturday sucked for so many reasons, but you know what, in a way it was needed. Like, this program had to see what big-time basketball looked and felt and sounded and smelled like. They'll be better for it. There's so much room to grow that it's ridiculous compared to last year. I'll always remember watching the Notre Dame game against St. Bonaventure on the plane ride to Los Angeles for the USC football game in November 22. It wasn't that the Irish lost (62-51) but it was the way they lost. Like, if that's what we were going to see from a supposed veteran team, it wasn't going to be any better in league play. It wasn't. Now, the ceiling is limitless. What's it all going to look like next year? The following year? Don't know, but can't wait to find out, right?

Clint from Winnipeg: I agree with you, Tae Davis has been the second-best player on the team after Markus Burton.Thomas Noie: Clint: And that's something that too few people understand. Like that's a massive jump for Tae Davis, doing what he's doing now compared to everything he did last year at Seton Hall. I know he's struggled from 3 (1-of-15), but I'll live with that given everything else he's been asked to do and has done. Lots of good stuff with Davis right now.

Justin, Ft Wayne: Hey Tom! I think the biggest thing for me is the lack of execution on the offensive end. The amount of shot clock violations is frustrating. I wonder why they don’t speed it up just a bit and see if that works. You have any reason or know why they like to play so slow?Thomas Noie: Justin: Probably because they're thinking the game too much. The more you think, the slower you play. Micah Shrewsberry has said plenty of times that he wants to play fast, wants the ball to pop and move and get the defense scrambled. But that's for later on down the line when these guys know one another better and trust one another more to just play. Now, you can almost see them thinking the game - overthinking the game - with every possession. Basketball's free flowing. They're not flowing, because they don't know how to yet.

Tyler from Granger: Now that we are 5 weeks into the season, what is the updated ceiling for this years' team? ACC tournament quarterfinals and let's say 15 wins?Thomas Noie: Tyler: Too early still to tell. You say the ceiling would be the Atlantic Coast Conference quarterfinals. That would mean winning at least two tourney games. Some would argue that this team might not win two league games. Micah Shrewsberry has said that he wants his guys to be playing their best basketball by the end of February and early March. If that's the case, there will be some long nights in January and early February. Let's see how they handle the next month before planning an extended stay in DC!😃

joe from the south side: Tom, If I recall correctly, Brey maintained a fairly "bare bones" staff. Under MS, the coaching staff has increased significantly. IYO, what benefits should ND realize from the new "Org Chart" and how much do you feel this improves ND's chances of success?Thomas Noie: Joe: Notre Dame won't lack from a player development standpoint. Brey's staffs (not always his choice) often rolled five deep. This one is eight. There's someone who knows the game at every turn. Micah Shrewsberry has been allowed more resources than Mike Brey ever had. That has to help. Kid wants someone to work him out late at night or early in the morning, someone on staff is there. Want to watch tape? Same thing. The extended staff guarantees nothing, but at least it puts it in the same ballpark as its conference peers.

Tyler from Granger: Tom, to play 6-7 home games during Christmas (out of their control, I get it) in the wintery snowy dark days of Michiana with a median town age population of what can feel like 72, why won't/doesn't the university try to reach out to our area high schools in filling up our student section with free tickets to create a better home advantage in our league games? I would take 1,000 16-18 year olds on their feet for those 6-7 games vs 400 (on a good day) sitting down only to sigh on a bad play & barely cheer for a good one. Not only that, as a season ticket holder, I would pay a little bit more annually to give those student tickets away during break to actually be used. I think about when I was in high school, all I wanted to do during hoops szn was get into that arena to watch our team play. There has to be hundreds of these kids in town now that were just like me then. These kids couldn't act/behave publicly any worse than these grown adults in SEC environments. I see no disadvantage. Thoughts?Thomas Noie: Tyler: Best idea I've heard in a while. You should be on the phone to the ticket office to give them some ideas. Some of the more surprising atmospheres over winter break has been when a local high school band is in the building. There's plenty of juice when there should be none. You're right on every aspect. Make it happen!

joe from the south side: Tom, Given the lack of experience with this group, wouldn't it be time for a European Tour in 2024?Thomas Noie: Joe: Preach. There is a plan in place for this group to go on a foreign tour. Last I heard it was going to be Spain, but those plans were still in its infant stages. If ever a team needs a foreign tour, it's Notre Dame next summer.

Clint from Winnipeg: Did J.R. Konieczny put on significant weight and muscle over the offseason? He looks much thicker than last year.Thomas Noie: Clint: He was listed as a true freshman in 2021-22 at 6-foot-6, 195 pounds. He's listed this year at 6-7, 204 pounds. He's not where he needs to be yet, but he's getting there. He can compete for longer stretches against bigger guys than he did his first two years. He plays hard, maybe as hard as anyone on the team. He's been better than anticipated.

Kurt in Ireland: Tom - I predicted JR would be one of, if not the most consistent player on the team in the last chat. He hasn’t quite met my expectations - and both Burton and Davis have exceeded my expectations, but I sensed a bit of Abro in JR from when I first saw him hit the floor as a freshman.Thomas Noie: Kurt: Man, people think I'M too critical of guys. J.R. Konieczny hasn't met your expectations? He's exceeded many with what he's done nine games in - two double doubles for points and rebounds to date (18 points, 11 rebounds against Auburn; 11-10 against Oklahoma State). Four games scoring double figures. The last seven games, he's played at least 23 minutes. He's averaging 9.0 points and 5.1 rebounds (second on the team) in 25.5 minutes. He's shooting .417 percent from the floor, .303 from 3 and .875 from the foul line. For someone who basically didn't play the last two years - since his freshman year of high school - what JRK has done to date has been solid. A great first step, with many more to come.

Kurt in Ireland: I wasn’t being critical - I was just saying that I’m not surprised how good he could be, as I saw that spark early on in his career. He just needed strength. It he where I had hoped? Not quite yet. He needs to hunt his shot a bit more and also cut more - though to be fair many times he’s been overlooked on cuts which is maybe why he’s been hanging in the perimeter more of late. That will come though, as you say, with trust.Thomas Noie: Understood, but nine games in after not playing for two years, JRK's been really good. Expectations don't kick in until January, especially for a program trying to tread water in the deep end. Gotta survive before you can swim! 😃

joe from the south side: Tom, Why did Brey take an assistant's job in the NBA? He is 64. He doesn't need the money. NBA players already know everything, so teaching them is out the window. He's a grandfather. I get Quin Snyder, but the rest doesn't add up. Please connect the dots.Thomas Noie: Joe: For the same reason that he was thisclose (OK, even closer than that) to taking the head coaching job at South Florida. Brey talked a good game about moving to Florida and being a grandfather and doing nothing but smoking cigars on the beach, but when the end came in Greensboro, North Carolina in March, and there was nothing next to do - no recruiting, no spring program, no nothing - that scared the $#%@$ out of him. Like, what now? He'd been a coach for so long that that was all he knew. He HAD to do something, so Quin Snyder, his old Duke buddy, offered the ultimate lifeline - come sit on the bench (really, the second row) in the NBA to keep yourself in the game. See if you like it. If you don't, the beach will always be there. And the money's not bad either. Brey's basically making $1.2 million to offer suggestions and be more of a sounding board than decision-maker. Every coach believes he can do it in the NBA. Brey gets the chance to scratch the itch. Pretty good soft landing, right?

joe from the south side: Tom, Agreed. But I think Brey fancied himself as more of a teacher/coach. If so, why not do what Rollie did? Go to FLA and take over a small school. That way you are in the game, you are teaching, and you are not dealing with 1 and done NBA wannabes.Thomas Noie: Joe: There likely was a provision/verbiage in his separation agreement with Notre Dame that said something to the affect of, if individual takes another college head coaching job before expiration of agreement (Brey was signed through 2024-25) then any future financial agreement would be nullified. That's probably one of the reasons he's not a head coach somewhere.

Kurt in Ireland: I wish Brey would go to booth for a while. I think he’d be a good commentator.Kurt in Ireland: Put him on a team with Bilas.Thomas Noie: Television wasn't an option for him. Seemed an easy one, yes, but it didn't do it for him. Maybe that changes.

joe from the south side: Tom, Since it is at least one year, maybe two, until ND Men's BBL games become competitive again, how do you psyche yourself up for for a 9PM start, on a snow covered WED night, right after the holidays to watch ND -NCST? Especially with your history experiencing all the magical moments of decades past?Thomas Noie: Joe: Easier than you and everyone might think. Every season is a journey. A new one with its own storylines and twists and turns and wins and losses. I don't cover this team thinking about how great of a ride it was in 2003 or 2010 or 2015 and 2016. It's about here and now with this head coach and this roster and this season - the challenges, the highs and lows, the everything. The past is the past. What's the present hold? The future? This is as different a journey as I've ever been on in my 26 seasons on the beat. What are we going to see? Can't wait to be there to find out, to think about it, to write about it. A 9 p.m. start? Maybe that's the game that everything turns. Or the following week. Or the the next one. LFG! 😃

joe from the south side: Tom, What gives you greater pleasure, watching a great ND BBL game (win or lose) or telling the fans about it in the SBT in your own inimitable style?Thomas Noie: Writing >>>>> everything else. Always.

Matt from St. Louis: I'm always interested in the dynamic between a coach and their kid at this level. Anything interesting about how either Shrewsberry has handled it so far?Thomas Noie: Matt: We're not around to see the good stuff (the practice court, film study, etc.). On the floor during games, Braeden's just one of the guys, and treated as such by Micah. If anything, he's a bit tougher on him. That's a difficult dynamic. Talked a little with Braeden about it in the fall (he's not one for many words) and he said that he's the head coach around campus and he's dad when they're at home. They have a good balance between the two.

Mickey, NY: Always good to have your chat on the calendar. Work got in the way this morning.Thomas Noie: You here now...bring it my man! Whatcha got?😃

Jim Tal, Valley Center CA.: Hi Tom, please provide a few reasons why ND fans should be interested in and should take the time to follow the Irish this season. What can make this team a viable and worthwhile watch? Thanks.Thomas Noie: Jim: That somebody has to sell someone on why they should watch Notre Dame men's basketball says a lot, doesn't it? Really? If you're expecting more wins than losses, you're not going to watch. If you're expecting more good basketball than bad basketball, you're not going to watch. If you want to jump in on the ground floor as this program is built back up, then you'll watch. If you want to see Markus Burton and Carey Booth grow their games as they grow up, you'll watch. Pretty simple - this season is a I-was-there-when situation for you.

Mickey, NY: The effort has been one of the things that has stood out but even that seems uneven. Games where the energy/execution isn’t there from the jump seems odd since CMS and staff are emphasizing that so much. Other than maybe not having exposure to differ t game environments and the “trust” thing you have mentioned previously what is Shrew’s view on that? (See what I did there?)Thomas Noie: Mickey: Goes back to the fact that they don't know what they don't know. Playing Marquette on the heels of hanging 86 points on Western Michigan set this team up for a total flameout in Milwaukee. It wasn't going to be as easy as it was back home against the Broncos. They had to be 10 times better than they were at the smallest of details. Shrewsberry and his staff can preach that all day every day (and likely did) but until the players were on the court at Fiserv Forum and saw it for themselves, they didn't know, Now they do. It's all been uneven because everything about this program is uneven. They'll eventually find that balance.

Mickey, NY: Have You heard anything about the connection to “Brey’s guys” and the new staff? I see Phonz and Cornette continuing their connectivity with the program. But no mention on X about what other guys might be doing in either the NBA or overseas (it used to pop up every so often). Is that something or a nothingburger?Thomas Noie: Mickey: There have been other players besides the obvious ones - Phonz, Cornette - that have reached out to Micah Shrewsberry. Pat Connaughton is down with an ankle injury right now, but he still showed up to the Marquette game in Milwaukee. A lot of the most recent guys are too busy playing professionally to play too much attention. And Shrewsberry, to be fair, has to be more concerned about coaching this team than worrying/working with the former guys. That's something for the spring, when the staff finally gets a chance to breathe.

Tyler from Granger: Tom, another ceiling question (sorry), who on this team do you think has the highest athletic professional ceiling? I'd say Tae Davis just based on his "point forward" position w his size, length, ability to defend the perimeter etc.. I'd say the old Matt Ryan situation though pretty much makes a question like this a dart throw anyway as far as predictability lolThomas Noie: Tyler: I love Tae Davis and what he's done to date, but when the lightbulb comes on for Carey Booth, whoa, watch out. He's got the biggest upside, which probably includes NBA-potential upside. Remember, he should still be a high school senior right now. He's so raw and unpolished. Get him in the gym, get him stronger, get him older and he might be the prototypical stretch 4. You see snapshots here and there to where you're like, man, when he gets it, he's really going to get it.

Frank from Mishawaka: I totally agree with one of your previous answers on the players Brey recruited and he told to wait out the hire. Those players could've helped the transition immensely. Last years team(upperclassmen) was very disappointing and something had to change. That being said, Shrewsbury has been given a larger support staff and even has 5 walk-ons. Was the larger support staff and walk-ons something Shrewsbury told his bosses had to happen for him to come here?Thomas Noie: Frank: I think it was more a case that the Notre Dame administration knew that if they were going to hire anybody who was serious about being a basketball coach that they had to get serious about the program. Mike Brey had lobbied to extend the staff for years, and was always told, yeah, no, make the best of what you have now. So he stopped asking. Shrewsberry's staff was extended at Penn State. If Jack Swarbrick came to him with an offer that didn't include a lot of what he already had, Shrewsberry would've been like, nah, I'm good. The staff, and the walk-ons, say that Notre Dame is serious about the program, more serious than they were when they were going to consecutive Elite Eights.

Mickey, NY: Your point about a guy who says “eff it, give me the ball and I’ll make it happen” has been the missing piece for a few years. Have you seen glimpses of anyone who might have it in them or is that person not on the roster yet?Thomas Noie: Nope. Nobody. The easy answer is Markus Burton because he's got the ball in his hands the most, but that #$%#@ guy might not be on the roster. Or the radar.

Tyler from Granger: Since covid, is your access to the team/program any different than before? As it relates to your day to day job, coverage, your travel to road games, accessibility to players and coaches, "inside" information, and all that? Or is/was it all about the head coach allowing it more than how times now, in general, are different?Thomas Noie: Tyler: Great question, and you're going to get an answer you probably weren't expecting. It wasn't so much COVID that changed how a beat writer does his job in covering Notre Dame men's basketball. You know what it was? Rolfs Hall, which changed the way we work, and a lot of it NOT for the better. Before Rolfs, we could/would talk with players before practice in the arena or the Pit. You could get a feel for them and them for you. You could talk with them as normal people, not writer/player. We've lost that at Rolfs, where pre-practice interviews with the last two head coaches are conducted in the lobby, one floor above the practice court. There are so few interactions now. The players are more insulated. That's not always the best way to go...Thomas Noie: Same for the post-game procedure. In the past, post-game interviews were held in the player lounge at Purcell Pavilion. We'd have three or four players scattered about - Ben Hansbtrough always sat in the same seat - and you could have a relaxed conversation with them. Now, players are brought to a dais in the conference room, where they say absolutely nothing. Or next to nothing. Getting away from that openess has closed down giving the coverage as much color as it deserves. Rant over.

Frank from Mishawaka: More on that give me the &%^^$# ball could that be Nasir Mohammed next year?Thomas Noie: Frank: I'll say maybe until I can see him on a college court playing with and against college players. 😃

Tyler from Granger: Might have been asked but have you had the opportunity to converse yet with Pete Bevacqua and what do you think his relationship will be with Coach Shrews as it relates to his interest in the investment of this program as well as his overall interest as a hoops fan (if at all) compared to his predecessor?Thomas Noie: Tyler: Pete Bevacqua, the athletic director in waiting if you will, hasn't opened up the media interview door. That's coming. I look forward to getting to know how he views basketball. Jack Swarbrick swore by Mike Brey. Let's see how the new regime rolls.

Jim Tal, Valley Center CA.: Tom, can you provide some insight as to what is going on with Zona. There was genuine hope that this season he would step up, elevate his game and become a real cornerstone guy. Instead, he's having very little impact and has seen his playing time being significantly cut. In your opinion, can Zona still become a factor as the season proceeds or is his window of opportunity rapidly closing?Thomas Noie: Jim: It's not a Matt Zona thing. It's a college basketball thing. A Micah Shrewsberry thing. If college basketball, if this head coach, relied more on the traditional two-big lineup look, Matt Zona might be a main rotation guy. But Shrewsbery prefers the 4-around-1 look of four perimeter guys to one big. That big is usually Kebba Njie, a player that Shrewsberry knew, recruited and took with him from Penn State to play a major role in preaching the Book of Shrews. So Njie's going to play. Sometimes, based on matchups, etc., the second big has been Tae Davis. There often aren't enough minutes to go around to get to Zona. We're not even to January and Zona already has set a career high for starts and assists. He's on his way to setting career highs for points and minutes and rebounds. It wasn't suddenly going to click for him after three years of basically nothing. He's a serviceable backup big. Every program needs/has guys like Matt Zona and Tony Sanders, regardless of their roles.

Justin, Ft Wayne: Any other away games that you’ll be at this year? How was your time at the away games this year?Thomas Noie: Justin: To be determined how often we'll travel this year. The more they win, that equation kind of works itself out. Travel never gets old, even after all these years. You don't like travel, you can't do this job.

Justin, Ft Wayne: I believe Tony Sanders and Matt Zona could be done after this year but also have the chance to comeback. You have any read on either one and what their decision may be? Just wondering from a scholarship perspective.Thomas Noie: Justin: If either wants to play, like really play, they'll probably have to go into the portal and move down a level to get major minutes. If they're serious about their educations, maybe they come back. But it might be a mutual decision for both sides to go different directions. If they leave, they both will have their degrees. That matters most in the big picture.

Frank from Mishawaka: Love your chats and wish more people would summit questions than bash the program(coaches, players, etc) on social media pages. People can get the insight that we the ordinary fan in the stands can't see everyday,Thomas Noie: Frank: Can't agree enough. Social media is a vital part of my job, but to look at my mentions on X (Twitter) at any point after any game last season (and some this year) is brutal. Sometimes, I think fan is short for idiot. Put an actual name to your thoughts and have an adult conversation about why something is the way it is about Notre Dame men's basketball. It's not hard. We're doing it just fine now. 😃

Jim Tal, Valley Center CA.: Tom, Swarbrick swore by Brey? I believe you because you would know but how come he didn't do more to get Brey some of the pivotal things he asked for and, in reality, truly needed?Thomas Noie: Jim: He did. Because it's Notre Dame, and they've done this or done that in a certain way for so many years, so they're going to still do it that way. Same reason why it took so long to get a stand-alone practice facility for hoops, and the Gug for football. They don't see the future very clearly over there. The past? They've got that part down! 😃

Mickey, NY: Given where the players are on the learning curve and where the team is, what games this season will be most useful to gauge growth, development and gaps? And don't say the last one or the penultimate one, please. I mean, what teams or environment will give us a view into this team?Thomas Noie: Mickey: Four come to mind between now and Jan 24. It's foolish to look any further ahead than that because, well, with this group, you just can't. The first one is the Virginia game at home on Dec. 30. Notre Dame will have three home games leading into that. Virginia is the first "marquee" home game - sorry Hoya Saxa. How will the Irish handle it? Next one is Duke on Jan. 6 - the third ACC home game. It's the fourth league game overall. Notre Dame will know the deal. Next after that is the road game vs. Georgia Tech on Jan. 9 - arguably the "easiest" road game to date. What has Notre Dame learned about playing on the road?Thomas Noie: Final one in this next long stretch is the rematch with Miami (Fla.) on Jan. 24 in South Bend. Notre Dame believes that it did a lot to really win that game on Dec. 2 in Coral Gables, but just didn't do enough. Now they get the Hurricanes in their gym. Will they do enough? If they do, that's another brick in the foundation they're building.

joe from the south side: Tom, John Brian Swarbrick was born in Yonkers, NY. His mother's maiden name was Comey. James Comey, former FBI Director, was also Irish Catholic and born in Yonkers, NY. Are they related? Always wondered about that.Thomas Noie: I'll save that for my Jack Swarbrick chat! 😃

Clint from Winnipeg: I can't believe how many people have seemed upset in the chat about how this season is going so far. I mean, we were last in the ACC last season and essentially half the rotation is true freshmen. (BTW, the prior complaint of a rotation comprised of 6-7 players now is a moot point with 9 guys regularly seeing action.) Let's enjoy the ride. It's going to be fun to watch this group grow up. search_result.title: Tax refunds are flowing, but IRS is seeing fewer early returns filed so ...
search_result.text:
The average federal income tax refund was $2,065 through Feb. 7.

The IRS has received fewer returns in the first two weeks of the 2025 season than it received a year ago.

Tax season continued its sluggish start into early February, but tax refunds continued to steadily roll out the door.

Every tax season has its own quirks and nuances. Oddly enough, though, the Internal Revenue Service has received 7.7% fewer returns so far this year. The agency also has processed 7.6% fewer returns through Feb. 7, according to the latest data published Friday.

Why the delays?

A variety of factors could be coming into play and keeping many people from filing their returns early in the game, including misleading online tax advice via social media, a flood of 1099-K forms, political rancor, some delayed deadlines in states hit by federal disasters, and the calendar itself.

How much money are people seeing in tax refunds?

The average federal income tax refund was $2,065 during this first two weeks of this year's tax season through Feb. 7, according to the IRS. That's up 18.6% from last year's tax season through Feb. 9, 2024.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Many times, those filing tax returns in late January and early February want to receive their refund cash as early as possible.

If you file your federal income tax return on Feb. 17, for example, you might anticipate a tax refund by Feb. 28 if you e-file, request that the refund by directly deposited into a bank account and the IRS has no problems with the return.

If you e-file the return Feb. 17 but want a paper refund check mailed to you, you could have to wait until March 7, according to estimates by CPA Practice Advisor, a resource for tax professionals. The publication notes that filing during peak season, which runs from late March through April 15, can result in slightly longer waits.

Many people who claim the earned income tax credit or the additional child tax credit need to anticipate delays. The IRS said taxpayers claiming those credits can expect to get refunds by March 3. That's if you file your return online, opt to get your refund by direct deposit, and have no issues with your tax return.

Some taxpayers, the IRS said, may receive their income tax refunds a few days earlier. The IRS "Where's My Refund?" tool is expected to show an updated status by Feb. 22 for most early filers who claimed the earned income tax credit or the additional child tax credit.

The IRS expects filing season numbers to even out as more tax returns come in during the weeks ahead and as the April 15 filing deadline for most taxpayers approaches.

How change in Washington has some rethinking their taxes

It's hard to judge why people could be putting off filing their taxes. But one reason could be that the new Trump administration isn't like the first Trump administration. We're seeing a lot of swift moves and, in some cases, outright chaos as President Donald Trump attempts to cut spending, offers buyouts and takes other dramatic steps to downsize the federal government.

After taking office Jan. 20, Trump issued a slew of executive orders. And some people wrongly might have thought that key tax breaks could hit their 2024 returns simply by executive order. It's not true.

Some social media buzz even suggested that Trump's proposed "External Revenue Agency" would replace the IRS and eliminate income taxes. But Trump did not eliminate the IRS or put an end to income taxes.

The tax breaks proposed on the campaign trail, such as no taxes on tips, are highly unlikely to come into play on 2024 returns retroactively the closer we get to April.

Mark Steber, chief tax officer at Jackson Hewitt Tax Service, said some bad information is floating on social media suggesting that taxpayers "wait and the IRS may go away.” Others suggest that changes will hit the IRS "and you will not owe taxes.”

Steber said that kind of silliness could have people delaying filing their tax returns for no good reason.

"I see virtually no chance of retroactive tax administration on political promises from the election," Steber said.

"If the changes happen at all, political statements rarely end up exactly as tax law changes and let alone retroactively," he said.

It's just hard to do, he added.

Tax law changes require a lot of agreement in Congress, where Republicans have slim majorities in both the House and Senate. There's much uncertainty about what will actually be proposed until Republicans in Congress get behind a particular tax plan.

When is Tax Day 2025? All about deductions, income brackets, credits and deadlines

"I think the 2026 tax year be the first year of real substantive change," Steber said. If so, taxpayers could see those changes when they file 2026 returns in 2027.

Several other factors, beyond potential tax cuts, could be contributing to a bit of a slowdown in the early tax season. They include:

A change in the tax season kickoff date

The 2025 tax season started two days earlier in 2025 than 2024, which one might imagine would generate more filings by now. But it didn't. The IRS has an explanation for that one.

This year, the IRS began accepting and processing e-filed income tax returns for individuals starting Jan. 27. Last year's tax season started Jan. 29 and the initial week's data ran through Feb. 2.

The IRS reasoned initially that many people this year didn't file in the first week because they might have still been waiting for key paperwork. Theoretically, the Jan. 29 kickoff last year was closer to a Jan. 31 deadline for W-2 forms to be issued by employers. The W-2 is a key form that reports income and tax withholdings. It's possible people had more paperwork in hand at the start of the season last year.

Many times, of course, tax filers now are able to get W-2 information online and avoid waiting for the documents to be sent in the mail.

The latest numbers do show improvements from the first week when the IRS processed 15.8% fewer returns than a year ago. During that week, the IRS reported that it received 14% fewer returns during the first week of the tax season compared with last year.

An expected flood of 1099-K forms

More gig workers are likely to receive a 1099-K this year that pinpoints how much money they made from these short-term jobs in 2024 — and some could be taking more time with their tax returns to figure out what to do.

Profits on the sale of things, like concert tickets, and money earned working a side hustle, such as delivering food, were always taxable. This year, though, some changes in the reporting rules mean more more people are getting tax forms that track the money.

Steber, at Jackson Hewitt Tax Service, said the larger number of tax forms, such as 1099-K forms and other forms, could be creating a feeling among some people that it's better to "wait until I have all my stuff."

And that's a good idea because you want to file an accurate return.

The 1099-K will usually arrive in late January or early February.

It wouldn't surprise me if many people are holding back to see what they need to do with a 1099-K if they never had to deal with one in the past.

This year, taxpayers will receive a 1099-K from payment card companies, payment apps, and online marketplaces when the amount of their business transactions during 2024 was more than $5,000.

Under the old standard, the 1099-K was only sent to those who had received more than $20,000 and had more than 200 transactions on third-party payment processing platforms in 2023 and earlier years.

The IRS receives these documents, too, meaning that a lower threshold means a bigger paper trail for 2024 income.

This same $5,000 threshold could apply if you sold Taylor Swift or Detroit Lions tickets through an online marketplace, such as StubHub, in 2024. The profit you made on those tickets would be taxable.

Overall confusion out of Washington

The IRS is dealing with its own disruptions this tax season, too. The White House initiated a hiring freeze at the IRS, which could be much longer than those hiring freezes facing other federal agencies.

Operations at the IRS are reportedly under review by Elon Musk's cost-cutting group, according to reports in Reuters and elsewhere.

Trump sent an email Saturday to supporters asking: "Are you sick of being harassed by the IRS? Well, maybe it's time that somebody audited them for a change."

The headline on the email: "Should I audit the IRS into oblivion?"

At one point, buzz was building that a new free online IRS service called Direct File had been killed by Musk, whom Trump has given broad authority to run a new “Department of Government Efficiency."

IRS Direct File was expanded to 25 states for 2024 tax returns. A post on X by Musk said: "That group has been deleted," triggering rumors in early February that Direct File was no more.

Many residents in these 25 states — but not all tax filers — are still able to use Direct File when they're filing their state and federal income taxes this year.

More than 30 million taxpayers in nearly half of the country can take advantage of the new, free program to prepare and file their federal income taxes online directly with the IRS.

Disaster relief

Millions of taxpayers can wait to file past the April 15 deadline based on federal disaster relief. While they might want to file earlier, they might also need to take their time.

Taxpayers in the entire states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina, and parts of Alaska, New Mexico, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia will have until May 1 to file their 2024 returns and pay any tax due. In addition, these taxpayers also would have until May 1 to file their 2023 returns.

On Jan. 10, the IRS announced an extension for victims of California wildfires. The tax relief applies to individuals and businesses in southern California affected by wildfires and straight-line winds that began Jan. 7.

These taxpayers in California now have until Oct. 15 to file their 2024 returns and pay their federal income taxes, based on disaster relief in any area designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

Many times, people want to file early to obtain their refund money. But many will wait, nonetheless, if they're dealing with the aftermath of a disaster.

Make no mistake, plenty of people have filed their tax returns early this year. The IRS data indicated that the agency received 23.58 million returns through Feb. 7. The IRS processed 23.5 million returns through the first two weeks.

It is key to note, though, that the IRS number for total tax returns processed includes tax returns received in the prior or current year and processed in 2025. The IRS hasn't processed nearly every 2024 tax return that it has received this year.

Matt Hetherwick, chief program officer for the nonprofit Accounting Aid Society in Detroit, said overall the nonprofit is actually seeing an increase in the number of tax returns prepared during the first weeks of this year's tax season.

"Our appointment scheduling is also seeing an increase in demand when compared to the same time last year," Hetherwick said.

Much of the tax work, he said, seems to be on track at this point.

"It is still very early in the filing season, so the earliest of filers would typically just now be getting refunds back," Hetherwick said.

"We are busy, and we have not received any calls from clients concerned with the length of time it's taken to receive their tax refund."

Contact personal finance columnist Susan Tompor: stompor@freepress.com. Follow her on X @tompor.

search_result.title: 'House of the Dragon' Season 3 is coming: What we know so far
search_result.text:
There is more to see from Team Black and Team Green.

The "Game of Thrones" prequel series "House of the Dragon" will return for a third season, despite what USA TODAY TV critic Kelly Lawler called an anti-climactic finale.

The HBO series, now streaming on Max and based on George R.R. Martin's "Fire & Blood" book, ended its second season on Sunday. The latest season, which premiered June 16, followed the ongoing fight for the Iron Throne of Westeros and was "uneven but often rousing."

Some fans were disappointed after what was seen as an abrupt and uneventful conclusion to the second season. But viewers should expect an action-packed third season, which is likely to kick off with a bang when it finally premieres.

Join our Watch Party! Sign up for USA TODAY's newsletter about all things TV and movies.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

What will the plot of 'House of the Dragon' Season 3 be?

Fans anxious to see what happens next in "House of the Dragon" can read Martin's "Fire & Blood," which includes the entire storyline of the series.

But those let down by the lack of major battles in the Season 2 finale can take comfort in the fact that based on the book, a highly anticipated one should come early in Season 3, perhaps as soon as the first or second episode. Part of the reason some fans were disappointed by the finale is many expected this battle, plus one other major event from the book that's coming up soon, to occur in Season 2.

During a featurette that aired after Sunday's finale, showrunner Ryan Condal teased that while Season 2 was about the "fits and starts" of war, Season 3 will be "about total war."

'Could've been an email': House of the Dragon finale leaves fans wanting more

'House of the Dragon' renewed for Season 3

Despite fan disappointment with the Season 2 finale, the series isn't going anywhere, as "House of the Dragon" was renewed for Season 3 ahead of the Season 2 premiere.

"George, Ryan, and the rest of our incredible executive producers, cast, and crew, have reached new heights with the phenomenal second season of 'House of the Dragon,'" said HBO programming Executive Vice President Francesca Orsi in a statement. "We are in awe of the dragon-sized effort the entire team has put into the creation of a spectacular season two, with a scope and scale that is only rivaled by its heart. We could not be more thrilled to continue the story of House Targaryen and watch this team burn bright again for season three."

The series is led by Martin as co-creator and executive producer with co-creator, showrunner and executive producer Ryan Condal.

When does 'House of the Dragon' Season 3 premiere on HBO?

"House of the Dragon" Season 3 has not yet received a premiere date on HBO.

But on Monday, according to Variety, Condal confirmed that the season will go into production in early 2025. After the long wait between Season 1 and Season 2, fans shouldn't expect to see Season 3 before 2026. Season 2 began production in April 2023 and premiered in June 2024, so based on that timeline, Season 3 could be eying a return around summer 2026.

In the meantime, another "Game of Thrones" prequel series, "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms," will air on HBO in 2025. Based on Martin's "Tales of Dunk and Egg," it follows the adventures of a knight named Ser Duncan the Tall and Prince Aegon Targaryen. A brief teaser for the show was released on Sunday.

How many seasons will 'House of the Dragon' last?

In a press conference on Monday, Condal addressed how many seasons "House of the Dragon" will last. "I think it's four," he said, according to Entertainment Weekly.

Martin previously said he expects "House of the Dragon" to last at least four seasons.

"It is going to take four full seasons of 10 episodes each to do justice to the Dance of the Dragons, from start to finish," the author wrote on his blog in 2022. In January, Martin also said he had been discussing the "third and fourth seasons" with Condal and the show's writers.

In a 2023 interview with Deadline, Orsi said the series will likely not have "any less than four" seasons and teased that there "could be more."

'Game of Thrones' star Kit Harington says Jon Snow spinoff is no longer in the works

Will there be any new characters in 'House of the Dragon' Season 3?

For book readers, one of the biggest questions throughout Season 2 was when, or if, the show would introduce Nettles.

In "Fire & Blood," Nettles is a major fan-favorite character who comes into play during the "dragonseed" storyline, in which numerous new dragonriders come forward. Described in the book as a "small brown girl" who grew up homeless, she was nowhere to be found in Season 2. The events of Sunday's finale strongly suggested that Nettles has been cut from the show, with aspects of her storyline given to Daemon's daughter Rhaena instead.

One character expected to be introduced in Season 3, though, is Alicent's other son Daeron. He has remained off screen for the entire series but was mentioned in Season 2, and his dragon Tessarion could be seen at the end of the finale, suggesting his proper introduction is imminent. No casting for Daeron has been announced.

How to watch 'House of the Dragon' Season 2 on HBO, Max

The Emmy-winning series airs on HBO. The show's first two seasons are also available to stream on Max, HBO's streaming platform, in full.

Today marks the first-ever meeting between Florida State football (0-3) and California (3-0) in program history. It is also Cal's ACC opener at Doak Campbell Stadium. Keep scrolling for the latest updates and highlights.

Florida State vs California score updates

FSU football highlights vs Cal

Defense carries Florida State football to victory over Cal

FSU's defense was swarming to Fernando Mendoza, resulting in a 14-9 victory. FSU improved to 1-3 on the season, while Cal dropped to 3-1.

Edwin Joseph came off a blitz to take down Mendoza, clinching the game for FSU. Mendzona was sacked seven times by the Seminoles' defense.

Patrick Payton leads the way with three sacks and 3.5 tackles for loss, tying with Joshua Farmer. Marvin Jones Jr added two, and Farmer had one.

DJ Uiagalelei finished the night by completing 16 for 27 passes for 177 passing yards, a touchdown, and an interception. Lawrance Toafili added 80 yards on the ground and a rushing touchdown.

Ja'Khi Douglas, who gave FSU's second TD of the night, led with four catches for 86 yards.

Defense, penalties, missed field goal, cost Cal three points

While Cal was moving the football well, it was not enough to put more points on the board.

After three straight penalties and a defensive stop by FSU's defense, Ryan Coe missed a 38-yard field goal, keeping 14-9 with six minutes to play. Coe is 3 for 5 in field goal attempts.

FSU QB DJ Uiagalelei throws an accurate 36-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver Ja'Khi Douglas. The Seminoles retake the lead at 14-9 with 11:09 left in the fourth quarter.

Douglas leads FSU with four catches for 86 receiving yards and a touchdown.

Uiagalelei is 16 for 26 in pass completions for 177 yards, a touchdown and an interception. It is the senior's second touchdown pass on the season.

Ryan Coe continued to put points on the board for Cal. The kicker nailed a 51-yard field goal to give the Golden Bears their first lead of the night, 9-7 before the third quarter end.

FSU has not scored since the first quarter, while Cal scored nine unanswered points. The Seminoles have the ball. It will be 2nd and 11 at FSU's 39.

Cal offensive lineman lays unconscious after suffering head injury

I was silent at Doak Campbell Stadium after a scary moment late in the third quarter.

Patrick Payton records his second sack to keep Cal's offense off the field

Cal's kick Ryan Coe misses field goal to remain 7-6

After FSU's offense missed an opportunity to score following a turnover, Cal ended the first half on a high note with a 29-yard field goal. FSU leads 7-6 at halftime.

FSU put up 208 total yards of offense. DJ Uiagalelei finished the half, completing 12 of 18 for 104 yards and an interception.

The Seminoles missed an opportunity to put more points on the board following an interception by Edwin Joseph.

Despite missing Kam Davis earlier in the first quarter, Lawrance Toafili picked up the slack as he rushed for 69 yards on 14 carries and one touchdown.

The Seminoles were also strong against the run, holding Cal to just 37 yards on the ground. Jaydn Ott led the way with 39 yards.

Cal scores following an FSU turnover
